error.signature: Fatal error: Uncaught Error: Class "App\SomeClass" not found

verdict.summary: Class not found errors in PHP 8.3 are almost always caused by incorrect namespace declarations, missing autoload mappings, or failing to run composer dump-autoload after adding new classes.

dead_ends.action: Manually require_once the class file everywhere it is used
dead_ends.why_fails: Creates brittle dependency chains, breaks when file paths change, and defeats the purpose of autoloading. Also fails in frameworks that expect PSR-4 autoloading.

dead_ends.action: Delete vendor/ and reinstall without checking namespace casing
dead_ends.why_fails: If the namespace or class name has a case mismatch with the file path (e.g., app/ vs App/), reinstalling dependencies will not fix the issue. Linux filesystems are case-sensitive.

workarounds.action: Verify PSR-4 namespace-to-directory mapping and run composer dump-autoload
workarounds.how: Check that the namespace in the class file matches the autoload PSR-4 mapping in composer.json. Ensure the directory structure matches the namespace. Run 'composer dump-autoload -o' to regenerate the autoload files.

workarounds.action: Check class name and file name casing on case-sensitive filesystems
workarounds.how: On Linux, verify that the file name exactly matches the class name including capitalization. For example, SomeClass.php must not be named someclass.php. Rename the file to match exactly.

leads_to.condition: when the missing class contained static utility methods that other code calls as functions

preceded_by.condition: when composer autoload configuration was recently changed

frequently_confused_with.distinction: Class not found is a PHP runtime error while composer autoload not found is specifically about composer's generated autoloader failing to locate the class
